channel.title: Visual Studio 6.0 Enterprise
channel.description: [code]http://d01.megashares.com/?d01=2f21122[/code] All tools, IDEs (except VJ++, but who ever used that?), etc. Serial: 1's all the way (as usual on vs6.0) Enjoy.

item.title: Visual Studio 6.0 Enterprise
item.dc:creator: @pkedpker pkedpker
item.description:
@pkedpker wrote:

but gotta see it this way…
vb6 is pretty weak langauge right for using it ur going to be declared as bad programmer anyways so switching .net wouldnt hurt managed code is good experience for C++ later… and in vb6 everything you build is single threaded unlike .net where you can have many workers on the same code

btw if u wanna start something in vs 2005 you should really download Visual Studio Net Video Tutorials.iso or something like that I downloaded 2 months ago really helps.

Read full topic

item.title: Visual Studio 6.0 Enterprise
item.dc:creator: @Pwnd Pwnd
item.description:
@Pwnd wrote:

I always had trouble with anything from Microsoft, IDE wise.

I’m going to go through it all again, though. I have both on my computer and hadn’t realized it. So, downloading this again was a waste -_-

Read full topic

item.title: Visual Studio 6.0 Enterprise
item.dc:creator: @DeadBird DeadBird
item.description:
@DeadBird wrote:

[quote=“pkedpker, post:4, topic:31943”]nope lol .net 2005 owns I’ve re-written Frank_'s RSC server in vb.net and it only takes up 244 KB of memory
you can port vb.net to C# with the built in converter
than C# to native C++
so you can program in vb and convert to C++ Lol.
vb6.0 is very limited in almost everything you have to built every function but in vb.net 2005 u can pick anything you want sort of like scripting all functions you need are all built in.

edit:

BTW soon all this vb6 is going to be useless anyways when windows vista goes on the market I believe every application in vista will be written in .NET expect for the core, also while googling for random boring stuff I found out that ms office suite is competely coded in vb.net off a digg site I forgot Lol.[/quote]
Oh man. I’m not going near vista if thats true.
And so what if vb6.0 is going outdated, vc6.0 is still one of the best C++ IDE’s, unlike 2005 where I tried to compile something, the first time I got a manifest verification error (or something like that), second time the same error, and on the third try it compiled.
However, 2003 was a good VS release.

Read full topic

item.title: Visual Studio 6.0 Enterprise
item.dc:creator: @pkedpker pkedpker
item.description:
@pkedpker wrote:

nope lol .net 2005 owns I’ve re-written Frank_'s RSC server in vb.net and it only takes up 244 KB of memory
you can port vb.net to C# with the built in converter
than C# to native C++
so you can program in vb and convert to C++ Lol.
vb6.0 is very limited in almost everything you have to built every function but in vb.net 2005 u can pick anything you want sort of like scripting all functions you need are all built in.

edit:

BTW soon all this vb6 is going to be useless anyways when windows vista goes on the market I believe every application in vista will be written in .NET expect for the core, also while googling for random boring stuff I found out that ms office suite is competely coded in vb.net off a digg site I forgot Lol.
